>You could log it, so that you know a given problem has occurred, then
>you could look at the resons that caused the error to fix the bug.  But
>you should then let the error filter up the chain to be handled by the
>correct error handler, or even halt the JVM process if it comes to that.

Well, you obviously aren't taking about a app server context. I agree with
you on a standalone app context. All of what you said is right in that
context (at least I think so). Now imagine a server with 10 000 concurrent
users, using 200 features. Then one clicks on a button (rarely used buggy
feature). One user, one feature. That could possibly make the JVM exit and
kick out all users? (of course you have clustering, but you still lost a
server).

>In this example, I would not catch Throwable, then.  I would catch
>NoClassDefFoundError.

Yeah, but the point is I don't know I'm going to have a
NoClassDefFoundError, else I would have a correct classpath / classloaders
configuration in the first place! :)
It could be a UnsatisfiedLinkError (missing rarely used, not-loaded-yet
library), a ClassCircularityError (bad class) a VerifyError (disk
corruption), etc...

>The only place where I /may/ catch Throwable explicitly, is at the very
>top of the call stack (main(), or some run() method), where I log the
>error before gracefully shutting down, or start some other recovery
>strategy.  However, this should only be done when a recovery strategy is
>available.  What do you do in the case of an OutOfMemoryError? (There
>are several solutions to this problem, but I won't mention them here.)

Well, if you don't catch, your server goes belly up and all sessions are
possibly lost. Angry users.
If you catch and log, your staff is now aware of the problem and the server
will probably be able to still serve people a couple of minutes and let the
time to the staff to check the problem and possibly gracefully take that
server out of the loop.

Usually when you have a correctly sized memory, a OOM will happend when a
thread goes wild crazy. When the craziness is stopped by a OOM, you get the
exception and all the crap the thread was using is released to the GC so you
automagically regain a lot of memory and everything is fine and dandy again.
Then you get a monitoring alert, find out the huge stupid bug and patch it.
But the server stayed up and nobody except the one user noticed it (maybe
they saw a slowdow for 5 seconds).

mathieu

> same. Also, you might want to make that "catch (Throwable t)"

I don't agree.  You should catch (<exceptions declared in throw
clause>).

> On this point, does anybody here catches Throwables inside his code?

I don't!

> I do. Even if not *supposed* to. Because when I "try"
> something, I want nothing to crap out except possibly that
> thing, and I want to know about it.

You could log it, so that you know a given problem has occurred, then
you could look at the resons that caused the error to fix the bug.  But
you should then let the error filter up the chain to be handled by the
correct error handler, or even halt the JVM process if it comes to that.

> For exemple, if there is a classpath problem preventing me to
> do X(), I want to catch the NoClassDefFoundError, log the
> error, and invoke my recovery strategy (msg to user,
> alternate method, etc..), Not let the error go all the way to
> the top and possibly stop some important top-level task (or
> worse the entire jvm process).

In this example, I would not catch Throwable, then.  I would catch
NoClassDefFoundError.

The only place where I /may/ catch Throwable explicitly, is at the very
top of the call stack (main(), or some run() method), where I log the
error before gracefully shutting down, or start some other recovery
strategy.  However, this should only be done when a recovery strategy is
available.  What do you do in the case of an OutOfMemoryError? (There
are several solutions to this problem, but I won't mention them here.)

Manuel Amago.
